It is surely important that we define what exactly we mean by 'namban 
tets=
u'.  Since the word 'namban', as adopted by the Japanese during 
the Heian =
period, was applied to all foreigners, irrespective of 
their origin, the t=
erm 'namban iron' should surely be applied to all 
iron not having its orig=
in in the smelting of native ore.

The importation of such iron into Japan =
from Korea is described in 
writings of the early part of the third century=
 AD, local production 
occurring only a few centuries later than this.  Nam=
ban iron thus 
existed in Japan many centuries before the Dutch arrival the=
re.

If, however, you consider - in my opinion, quite wrongly - that the 
t=
erm 'namban iron' refers to that of a European source, the Dutch 
started t=
o import iron, with its origins in China, Korea and India, 
in the early C1=
7.  Iron and steel were both imported by the Dutch and 
the English during =
the C17.

Finally, in defining the term, does one include under the heading=
 
locally produced iron that contains a proportion of the metal from 
forei=
gn sources? If so - as I believe one should - only iron produced 
locally, =
exclusively from the smelting of local ore, can be excluded 
from the label=
 of 'namban iron'.

JPL.
